Fields.DialogueText: Konnichiwa, Kanchou. Is it true?
Hello to you, too, Kamikaze.
The navigator reports that we are now steady on a course of zero-four-zero. Is it true or not?
It's true. We're heading back to Japan for a brief stop in Tokyo.
Sugoi! I was a bit bored with our patrols around Formosa.

Fields.MenuText: It was an important duty, right? Ensuring the emperor's territories were safe?
I'm ready for a change.
You think patrol duty is beneath you.

Fields.DialogueText: It was important, and we did it.
As am I.
I consider patrol duty without action beneath us, yes.
We're the emperor's ichiban destroyer, Kanchou. We can always do more.
Well, whatever comes next, at least you'll see the homeland for a bit.
Hai!
Let's look good for our homecoming, shall we?
I will mobilize the crew at once.
Remind them that Morganas come first. Cleaning the ship comes second.
Consider it done.
@BATTLE
Ready for inspection, Kanchou.
Thank you, Kamikaze. Hand me that white glove.
Here it is. Good luck finding any dirt or oil with that!

Fields.MenuText: I like that confidence.
Let's get started, then.
Is that a challenge?

Fields.DialogueText: And I will always strive to earn it.
At once, Kanchou.
Shall me make it one? I will accept any stakes you wish to set.
Hm.
Hmm.
Any troubles, Kanchou?
No.
I'm waiting.
Hmmm.
No dirt or oil on that white glove yet?
None! Great job with the inspection, Kamikaze. Tell the crew I'm pleased with the ship's cleanliness.
I will inform them at once.
*ALARM*
First things first. Morganas approaching.
Those damn Funayūrei had better not leave a stain on this perfectly clean ship!
@BATTLE
One thing at a time, Kamikaze.
Reporting as ordered, Kanchou.
I heard loud banging and popping noises from the weatherdecks.
You did.
Let me guess.
You expressed your appreciation for the crew's inspection performance with... a performance of your own.
*drums* A tsugumi drum performance, hai!

Fields.MenuText: I guess your traditional Japanese music, uh, said what words couldn't?
Your enthusiasm probably, um... inspired them greatly.
I'm sure they loved it.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai.
Indeed. They were inspired to sprint to their posts as soon as I finished.
Hai. They said nothing, but their silence was probably just an expression of respect for my music.
Well, your drumming is fine with me, as long as I don't mistake it for gunfire or explosions.
Oh! I wonder if I could reach that level of skill...
For now, I'd like you to focus on keeping us ship-shape and ready for combat, Kamikaze.
I will, Kanchou. Funayūrei may arrive at any--
*ALARM*
Time?
Honto desu ne.
@BATTLE
Okinawa is visible off the starboard bow, Kanchou.
Yes, Kamikaze. Just like it was visible off the starboard bow five minutes ago.
Did I report it once already?
That was your fourth report, actually.
Oh.

Fields.MenuText: Anxious to see home?
Is there something you aren't telling me?
Are you losing your mind?

Fields.DialogueText: Hai, but not because of homesickness.
The sense of urgency I feel is difficult to contain.
No, of course not! I just...
I always want to make sure Japan is safe and well.
Well, in wartime, that can never be certain.
That's why I want to hurry.
Stay focused. Keep scanning the horizon, not just Okinawa.
Aye aye, Kanchou. Morganas will not take me by surprise.
That's all I ask.
*ALARM*
Speak of the Funayūrei devils.
@BATTLE
Should I ask why you've been walking around the ship smelling whatever's in that bag?
*sniff* What?
That bag. You keep sniffing it.
Ah, yes! Here, put your head into the bag and inhale.
What?!
Trust me.
I, uh...
Hayaku!
What the hell? I'm the captain of this--
Hey! It's dark with this bag on my head.
Stop complaining and please tell me what you smell.
Fine. It smells like...

Fields.MenuText: ... like disrespect for a senior officer.
... like fish.
... like yellowfin tuna.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps your sense of humor is too subtle for me to grasp.
Not just any fish. Yellowfin tuna, Kanchou.
I am impressed, Kanchou! That's exactly what it is.
Although we couldn't stop for long in Okinawa, I managed to get a small shipment of yellowfin tuna for us.
That sounds delicious, but-
It is. A true Japanese delicacy.
-but I'm taking my head out of this bag.
Of course, Kanchou.
If there's enough for the whole crew, then let's make a meal out of it.
Hai. Perhaps these incoming Morganas will let us work up an appetite.
Incoming Morganas?
You probably didn't see them because you had your head inside of a bag.
You think?!.
@BATTLE
What a complete disaster...
Is something troubling you?
I'm distressed at the lack of respect our crew shows for Japanese traditions, Kanchou.
This must have something to do with the yellowfin tuna sushi.
The crew didn't like it.

Fields.MenuText: Nonsense. I'm sure they loved it.
Maybe they'd prefer it cooked.
You're trying too hard.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe some did, but not all of them.
Unacceptable!
Ie. I didn't try hard enough.
This crew needs to appreciate Japanese cuisine and culture!
I admire your dedication, but keep things in perspective.
A warship must run properly in every aspect.
I won't argue with that, but combat performance comes first.
I... I understand, Kanchou.
Kamikaze?
What?
Just so you know, I liked the tuna. It was delicious.
Arigatō, Kanchou. I appreciate that.
@BATTLE
Enemy inbound! Full speed into battle!
@BATTLE
Line up on the quarterdeck! You will be permitted to go ashore in Tokyo only when I allow it. Understood?
Yes, Kamikaze.
Yes, Kamikaze.
Yes, Kamikaze.
Step forward and let me inspect you. If your uniform and hygiene are perfect, you will be permitted to go into Tokyo.
Yes, Kami-
But if I inspect you, and you are NOT READY, you will be confined to your quarters for the night.
I see. Is anyone else ready to be inspected?
Then don't come back until you are! I will not permit filthy sailors to go on liberty in Tokyo.
Looks like they all left to double check their uniforms.
It would seem so.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you have high standards.
You're being too hard on them.
Do whatever you think is right.

Fields.DialogueText: And I'm glad at least one person on board appreciates that, Kanchou.
A warship must be a hard place, Kanchou.
I always do.
When you're done here, come find me in my cabin.
Hai.
@BATTLE
*Knock*
Come in.
Forgive my delay. I had to ensure the crew was ready to go ashore into Tokyo.
How many did you confine to their quarters for failing?
Not many. After the first two were confined, the rest learned quickly.

Fields.MenuText: Your methods are effective.
That was harsh.
I'm glad you took care of it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you approve, Kanchou.
But necessary. The others learned from their example and improved.
Doitamashite. You are welcome.
Now that you're done, I thought you could join me for a meal.
Really?
I know you can't leave the ship, so I had some street food brought up here that we could enjoy together.
I thought I smelled something familiar.
Some yakitori, some ramen, and a few doriyaki.
Doriyaki cakes? I...
Sounds like I did good. Shall we eat?
Itadakimasu!
Finally. Long day done, paperwork filed. I can actually think about getting some sl-
*ALARM*
Even as I was talking I knew I was asking for trouble.
Kamikaze, try looking at the ocean in front of us instead of looking back at Tokyo.
I was just... checking for weather patterns behind us.

Fields.MenuText: If you say so.
Tokyo will still be there when we return.
Focus on the mission.

Fields.DialogueText: I do say so.
The homeland is first in my mind, Kanchou.
Of course.
I have heard we can expect heavy Morgana resistance on this war patrol.
True. At least you won't be bored, right?
I am eager to teach the Funayūrei what each of my guns can do.
That opportunity is coming soon.
@BATTLE
You seem relaxed. Looks like you enjoyed the stop in Tokyo.
I did enjoy it, Kanchou. Thank you for enjoying it with me.
Did you enjoy it enough that you won't mind another boring patrol assignment?
It won't be boring. We will see action.

Fields.MenuText: That's a confident prediction.
You can't know for sure.
That's what a warship is built to do.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai.
The war will always find us, or I will find it. Either way, we will be ready.
Not just any warship! Japan's ichiban destroyer, Kanchou.
You're calm because you're prepared for it?
Yes, but also, there is something else.
These waters are familiar to me.
I take comfort in that as I serve to protect Japan.
Sounds like you're ready for anything.
Hai.
@BATTLE
Make your report, lookout. What did you see?
It was dark... It was hard to see, ma'am...
Stop babbling! Have some confidence and tell me what you saw.
Ugh! Dismissed, lookout. Return to your post, for whatever good it will do.
Is everything all right?
I cannot get reliable answers. The lookouts are reporting ridiculous things.
What sort of ridiculous things?
Large, dark shapes on the horizon. Black silhouettes.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe it's a Morgana.
They're teasing you.
Maybe they're telling the truth.

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't sense any Funayūrei.
Would they be so bold to tease me? I think not.
Impossible.
I just... can't imagine the possibility.
Just say it, Kamikaze.
The possibility that we are being stalked by an umibōzu.
An umi-
*ALARM*
We're not finished here. Talk to me again after this.
Hai. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Morganas spotted to the north.
I sense them, Kanchou. All main guns are ready for action.
Let's send them packing, Kamikaze.
Hai.
@BATTLE
The Funayūrei have been dispatched, Kanchou.
With spirited efficiency as usual, Kamikaze. Nice work.
Is there anything else you wish me to add to the after-action report, Kanchou?
Explain what you mean.
Anything from the combat that seemed... unusual?

Fields.MenuText: Nothing.
Did anything seem strange to you?
Is this about that umibōzu thing you mentioned earlier?

Fields.DialogueText: Very well, Kanchou.
I am not sure.
If you have something to say, say it.
Please forget that I said anything, Kanchou. Perhaps I should just get some rest.
If you change your mind, you know where to find me.
Of course.
What's all of this junk doing on the weatherdecks, Kamikaze?
Forgive me, Kanchou. I was about to scold the crew for leaving this clutter lying about.
Are those wooden barrels?
Hai. It would seem the crew made some crude barrels out of scrap wood.
I don't understand. These barrels don't even have bottoms.

Fields.MenuText: Are they afraid we'll run out of drinkable water?
Are they trying to make alcohol?
What do you think is going on here?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't think that is the situation, Kanchou.
I don't think that is the situation, Kanchou.
I think I have an explanation, Kanchou.
The umibōzu, the mythical Japanese demon, could be to blame.
How so?
The umibōzu is described as a giant black figure, one which destroys ships. It demands a barrel, which it then uses to pour seawater onto the ship until it sinks.
So, if the barrel does not have a bottom...
Then the umibōzu cannot pour seawater onto us.
Kamikaze...
Yes?
You're not really taking this seriously, are you?
Kanchou, I... I think that...
*ALARM*
We will talk about this later, Kamikaze. Get these barrels out of the way, and make sure our guns are ready.
Hai, Kanchou.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
The door is unlocked, Kamikaze. Come in.
Thank you, Kanchou.
Have you ever considered replacing your cabin door with shoji? A sliding screen would be more...
Traditional?
Hai, and graceful.
I'll give it some thought. So, tell me about the barrels.
It goes beyond a few barrels and umibōzu, Kanchou. The crew is spreading rumors of other Japanese yokai and demons, too.

Fields.MenuText: That's unprofessional for a modern warship.
At least they know some Japanese folklore. I hadn't even heard of umibōzu until you explained it.
Do you think they're mocking you?

Fields.DialogueText: I agree...
Small comfort, Kanchou.
I can't tell if they're mocking me or if they actually believe it.
Do you think these rumors are a legitimate possibility?
I keep asking myself that question. I suppose if Morganas are real, why not umibōzu? Or something like them?
You're my sea monster expert, Kamikaze.
I will think about it some more.
And get some rest, too. Dismissed.
Hai.
Sea monsters? What the hell is going on around here?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Kamikaze, you're littering sheets of paper everywhere.
Do not concern yourself with the mess.
When you're taking notes, I'm more concerned about what you're going to tell me.
I collected information about any recent unusual phenomena at sea from other ships and observations from our crew.

Fields.MenuText: Did you ask Command for information, too?
Did you check the local library for ghost story books?
Tell me what you found.

Fields.DialogueText: Not yet.
At once, Kanchou.
Other ships have reported strange lights and unexplained noises.
But?
But these reports are typical. Nothing here matches what our crew has claimed to observe.
So, what about our crew?
At least a dozen reports of spotting sea monsters, hearing bizarre voices, and having more nightmares than usual.
Maybe I should look at these reports myself.
I would appreciate that. While you do, I will return to enforcing crew discipline and cleanliness.
Good idea. Take your mind off of this for a bit.
Kamikaze, what have you gotten us into?
@BATTLE
Afraid they'll laugh?
Looks like the seas are calm for now, so I'll have a look at Kamikaze's notes.
Hm.
Hearing strange voices... nightmares...
Oh, and that weird thing with the barrels and the umibōzu...
Nothing in these notes correlates to observed phenomenon in the rest of the fleet.
Maybe Kamikaze has been a little too focused on Japanese tradition, lately.
*KNOCK*
Kanchou, I intend to put on a tsugumi performance to entertain the crew. Any objections?

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps the crew could use a break from Japanese tradition.
Drive away the evil spirits with your drums.
None at all, Kamikaze. Play as loud as you want.

Fields.DialogueText: That is a clever joke. I am starting to understand Western sarcasm, even if I don't appreciate it.
Sugoi. It would be good to relieve some stress.
Have fun, and entertain the crew.
Arigatō, Kanchou.
*sigh*
Thank you all for your respectful attention and appreciation of my tsugumi performance.
Kamikaze, a moment please.
Dismissed.
Hai...
H-hai.
Kanchou, what is it?
We need to talk.

Fields.MenuText: I fear the crew is losing their minds.
I fear your focus on Japanese folklore is adversely impacting the crew.
I'm worried I'm starting to think that these monsters are real.

Fields.DialogueText: That may be so, but why?
Perhaps I've been too fixated on the supernatural...
Kanchou, are you having nightmares, too?
What are we going to do about this?
I think we need to stay calm and observe as much as we can for ourselves. Get to the root of what's actually going on.
Most of the problems occur at night, so perhaps we should stay up late and keep watch.
Let's do it together.
I will try to get some rest so that I will be ready.
*ALARM*
Kuso!
@BATTLE
Enemy inbound! Full speed into battle!
@BATTLE
Konnichiwa, Kanchou.
Did you see anything strange when you were on the bridge?
Nothing. In fact, I feel much better after getting some sleep.

Fields.MenuText: Me too.
I'm tired, but I'm glad you're feeling better.
We're kidding ourselves. There's a demon out there somewhere.

Fields.DialogueText: I am relieved to hear that.
Perhaps you should try to take a nap. I can handle things for a while.
You should definitely take a nap. Trust me, you will feel better once you do.
Maybe the crew needs more rest, too.
I don't like to go easy on them, but we could let them get more sleep until the rumors and nightmares go away.
It's worth a shot, I suppose.
Thank you for trusting me with this, Kanchou.
Relax, and everything will be fine.
Oh, yes... Everything will be fine...
Why did you say that twice, Kamikaze?
That wasn't me...
Go get some sleep... Let the nightmares come...
What the hell is going on?!
Battle stations!
But there's nothing there!
All lookouts have reported. No strange ships or... demons... were sighted.
You heard that strange voice.
I did if you did.
I did.
Kuso.
What about the crew? Did anybody else report hearing it?
No.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe they were afraid to report it.
Maybe the demon only spoke to us.
Maybe we're both going nuts.

Fields.DialogueText: That is disappointing, but I can respect their reasons if it were so.
If it really is an umibōzu...
Kanchou, we cannot let that happen!
I want all visual and radar contacts analyzed immediately. There must be an explanation.
Kanchou, I think I sense the presence of...
*ALARM*
Morganas off the port beam. Guns up, Kamikaze!
Hai!
@BATTLE
Enemy inbound! Full speed into battle!
@BATTLE
You cannot deny my power, Captain...
What?!
Kanchou, I feel that strange presence again. It's familiar, but...
Nothing in the sea is safe from me...
Captain, bring me a BARREL!
Who are-
Kanchou, no! Don't answer it!
Don't worry. Whatever it is, I'm not giving it a barrel.
But... if you even speak to an umibōzu...

Fields.MenuText: It will attack?
It will put a curse on me?
It will confirm that I'm losing my sanity?

Fields.DialogueText: Hai, it is trying to lure you in!
Ie, that will make it attack!
Ie, you are not going crazy. I can hear it, too.
Why don't you answer me, cowards?
I am leaving, but I challenge you. Follow me to the north and face me... if you dare.
Is it... gone?
Hai. For now. I don't feel it anymore.
Did that really just happen?
Excuse me, Kanchou. I must prepare our course to the north.
Kamikaze, get back here!
Kamikaze, do not put us on a course to the north. We're not going.
But we must. I am taking us north to follow the... umibōzu.
That's a mistake for two reasons.
One, we don't know the truth of the situation. This is likely to be a tactical blunder.
Hai.
And two, this is-
Insubordination. Yes, I know it must seem that way to you.

Fields.MenuText: It seems like insubordination because it is insubordination.
That's not really an umibōzu. This is a trick.
Why are you doing this?

Fields.DialogueText: It is a challenge.
That doesn't matter. We have been challenged.
We have been challenged.
We will not back down in shame. Japan's ichiban destroyer will accept that challenge.
You want to accept the challenge of a umibōzu?
We're going north to confront... it.
*ALARM*
You are going to explain yourself.
I will, once more urgent matters are resolved. Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Kamikaze, I‘ve come to expect a certain amount of stubborn and insubordinate behavior from you. It has been manageable so far.
Kanchou, I-
I wasn't finished.
Hai.
First you will back down on all engines. The ship stops here until I have answers.
That's an order. Dead in the water, Kamikaze.
Hai.
Then you will wait until I am done speaking.
Hai.
Your behavior has been difficult ever since Tokyo.
I can explain--
Did I let our relationship become too casual? Did a shared meal in Tokyo make you think you didn't need to respect your captain?
No, Kanchou! I promise you that is not the case. It pains me to see I have given you cause to think so.
Listen carefully. I must speak softly. That voice we heard is not an umibōzu. I know what it is now.
So, it's not a mythical creature from Japanese folklore. Wonderful.
You have every right treat me with sarcasm...
Don't keep me waiting.
*ALARM*
Ugh!
@BATTLE
I apologize deeply for my ruse, but it was necessary to outsmart the "umibōzu."
I believe we've been followed since Tokyo by the Funayūrei Venom. She enjoys poisoning thoughts, and I'm sure she's used my appreciation of Japanese folklore to her advantage.
Venom has been lurking beneath our hull, whispering to us and planting nightmares of ancient monsters.
When did you figure this out?
I've felt her Funayūrei presence at times, but she's remained so far below the waves, it's been difficult for me to identify her.
I first recognized her voice when she spoke directly to us, demanding a barrel as an umibōzu would.
You seemed convinced that if I spoke to that voice, we would be destroyed.
I regret the deception, but I did not want her to know I had solved her riddle.
Even now, she hopes we will fearfully avoid her challenge and stay clear of her lair.

Fields.MenuText: Then we have no choice.
What if we leave her alone?

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly.
If we don't stop her here, she'll return to Tokyo and terrorize other Japanese ships. Not just warships, but fishermen and merchants, too.
It's decided. We follow her north.
Hai.
Probably right into an ambush with other Morganas.
Perhaps, but without irrational fears of an umibōzu. We know she is just a Funayūrei.
And you can't let that challenge go unanswered, can you?
This is the right decision, challenge or not.
Take us north, Kamikaze.
@BATTLE
I sense her presence, Kanchou. She is lurking nearby.
Call her out.
Oh great "umibōzu," we accept your pathetic challenge!
Impudent little ship! You will die of fright when I reveal my form to you!

Fields.MenuText: I doubt that.
Show yourself!
I'll try not to laugh at how ugly you are.

Fields.DialogueText: But you will! To see the umibōzu is to see your death...
I am coming for you...
You will learn humility at the bottom of the ocean!
Give me a barrel so that I may sink and drown you!
I have a barrel for you.
Oh? Then give it to me, and receive your death in return...
Come up and look at my guns! I will give you more barrels than you can handle, filthy Funayūrei!
We know you're just a Morgana, not an umibōzu.
How... clever of you to see through my ruse.
But it makes no difference. You will be sent to the ocean floor regardless!
@BATTLE
Enemy inbound! Full speed into battle!
@BATTLE
Hurry, Kanchou. Your tea is getting cold.
Sorry to keep you waiting. I wanted to make sure Command acknowledged receipt of our mission report.
Of course. It could help other ships avoid similar problems with Funayūrei like Venom.
You didn't really think she was an umibōzu, did you?
Ha! You are embarrassed to say yes!
Admit it, Kamikaze. For a while, you weren't sure either.
I... I admit it.
I'm sorry for being so harsh with you earlier.
You had every right. I didn't want Venom to know her disguise had failed, but you had no way of knowing what I was doing.
I appreciate that.
Um, this tea isn't bad, but wouldn't a few glasses of shochu be better?
Shochu?
Tea is good for a Belle and her captain, but friends can drink shochu together, can't we?
Friends? Hai, I think I would enjoy that, Kanchou.
Get this tea out of the way and start pouring.
Kampai, tomodachi!
Cheers, friend.
